marriage.title: Marriage (The Great Paradox)
marriage.description: Reality: Religious marriage - contract before a cleric (not officially registered)
marriage.details:
She lives in a 'legal shadow' without rights; her marriage is conducted outside the court, and its official registration is left to later stages such as pregnancy, childbirth, or dispute.

Although this type of contract existed before the issuance of the 'Ja'fari Code' and is considered a violation of Personal Status Law No. 188 of 1959, the Code gave these practices wider legitimacy and weakened the criminalization of marriage outside the court by not specifying a minimum age for marriage and allowing the marriage of minors without judicial oversight.

Thus, a child in elementary school is labeled a 'wife' by custom, while being effectively deprived of the legal protection system related to capacity, age, and judicial guarantees.
marriage.law: Personal Status Law No. 188 of 1959 ‚Äì Article (8): Regulation of marriage age and criminalization of marriage outside the court. Amendment Law No. 1 of 2025 ‚Äì Stipulation not to reduce the marriage age. The Ja'fari Code ‚Äì Article (2/Fifth): Sufficiency of the condition of puberty and reason without a specific age. ‚Äì Article (18): Permitting the marriage of a minor by the father or paternal grandfather. Rahim Al-Ukaili: What Women Lost in the 'Ja'fari Code'

legalCapacity.title: Legal Capacity
legalCapacity.description: A minor does not have the authority to sign official or legal contracts; the "guardian" acts on her behalf.
legalCapacity.details: A minor does not have the authority to sign official or legal contracts; the "guardian" acts on her behalf. Important transactions are subject to the oversight and supervision of (Minors Welfare Directorate) to ensure the protection of her rights.
legalCapacity.law: Article (97) of Iraqi Civil Law No. 40 of 1951. Minors Welfare Law No. 78 of 1980.

civilRights.title: Civil Rights
civilRights.description: A passport cannot be issued for a minor or allow her to travel outside Iraq without written consent from the "guardian".
civilRights.details: A passport cannot be issued for a minor or allow her to travel outside Iraq without written consent from the "guardian" as she lacks the capacity to make this decision alone.
civilRights.law: Article (6) of Iraqi Passport Law No. 32 of 2015.

marriage.title: Marriage (The Great Paradox)
marriage.description: "The judge may authorize marriage for those who have completed fifteen years if necessary..."
marriage.details:
The problem: Guardian consent may be coercive, and 'necessity' is interpreted loosely.

Despite all the previous restrictions... if a minor gets married, the law suddenly considers her "fully competent"!
The marriage contract grants her the status of "adulthood" immediately, making her legally and financially responsible like adults, as if marriage gave her the mental maturity she lacked moments before.
marriage.law: Article 8 of Personal Status Law Article (3 / Paragraph 2) of Personal Status Law No. 188 of 1959.
